security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing only documentation and structured prompts. No executable code, no file system access, no network calls, no environment variable access, and no external command execution. The skill provides educational slide generation workflows for NotebookLM through browser automation.

content.value_statement: Creating chapter slides is time-consuming and often produces generic, text-heavy presentations. This skill provides proficiency-calibrated prompts for NotebookLM to generate pedagogically-aligned slide decks with clear narrative arcs and actionable endings.
actual_capabilities: Generate slide decks calibrated to CEFR levels (A2 beginner to C1 advanced)
Create pedagogically-aligned presentations with 3-7 bullet points per slide
Structure narratives following problem → transformation → opportunity → action arc
Provide ready-to-use prompts for NotebookLM browser automation
Validate slide output against 7 success criteria gates
limitations: Requires NotebookLM account and daily generation limits apply (3-5 chapters per day)
Requires browser-use skill for automated slide generation workflow
Does not generate slides directly; provides prompts that users submit to NotebookLM
Does not create static slides or non-educational presentations

use_cases.title: Create Chapter Presentations
use_cases.description: Generate slide decks for each chapter with content matched to student proficiency levels

use_cases.title: Build Training Materials
use_cases.description: Create detailed C1-level slides with architecture diagrams and decision matrices

use_cases.title: Develop Beginner Courses
use_cases.description: Produce encouraging A2-level presentations with simple language and actionable endings

prompt_templates.title: A2 Beginner Slides
prompt_templates.prompt: Create inspiring slide deck for absolute beginners (A2 proficiency). AUDIENCE: Complete beginners with no programming experience. Include 3-5 principles: simple explanation, accessible mental model, encouraging tone. Themes with concrete numbers. 12-15 slides with 3-5 bullet points each. END WITH: Specific next steps.

prompt_templates.title: B1 Intermediate Slides
prompt_templates.prompt: Create comprehensive slide deck for intermediate learners (B1 proficiency). Include problem-solving approaches and real-world applications. 15-20 slides with practical examples and case studies. Balance theory with practice. END WITH: Implementation strategies.

prompt_templates.title: C1 Advanced Slides
prompt_templates.prompt: Create detailed slide deck for advanced practitioners (C1 proficiency). Include theoretical frameworks, industry patterns, and critical analysis. 20-25 slides with architecture diagrams and decision matrices. Use industry-standard terminology. END WITH: Production deployment strategies.

prompt_templates.title: Batch Chapter Processing
prompt_templates.scenario: Generate slides for multiple chapters efficiently
prompt_templates.prompt: Process chapters 1-5 using batch workflow. Create notebooks first, upload all sources, then generate sequentially. Track daily limits. Download and rename each slide deck as chapter-NN-slides.pdf. Validate each against 7 success criteria.

output_examples.input: Generate A2 beginner slides for a Python programming chapter about variables
output: 12-15 slide deck generated with A2-calibrated language
Each slide contains 3-5 bullet points as sentences
Narrative arc: Variables solve the problem of remembering values → Transformation with concrete examples → Opportunity to write code → Action with specific first steps
Slide 1: 'What Are Variables?' with simple definition and box metaphor
Slide 5: 'Try It Yourself' with specific code exercise
Final slide: 'Your First Variable' with step-by-step instructions

best_practices: Always specify proficiency level (A2, B1, C1) and provide concrete audience description
Include explicit slide format requirements (bullet count, slide range, NOT paragraphs)
Validate generated slides against all 7 success criteria before deployment
anti_patterns: Using vague audience descriptions like 'beginners' instead of specific levels
Skipping framework principles results in generic, non-pedagogical output
Leaving slide format as default produces text-heavy, ineffective presentations

faq.question: What proficiency levels are supported?
faq.answer: A2 (beginners), B1 (intermediate), and C1 (advanced) with calibrated prompts for each level.

faq.question: How many slides does each level generate?
faq.answer: A2: 12-15 slides, B1: 15-20 slides, C1: 20-25 slides with varying bullet depths.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, it requires the browser-use skill for browser automation and NotebookLM web interface.

faq.question: Is my educational content safe?
faq.answer: Content is only uploaded to NotebookLM via browser. No data is stored or accessed by this skill.

faq.question: Why did my generation get stuck?
faq.answer: Check NotebookLM daily limits (3-5 chapters per day) or browser console for error messages.

faq.question: How is this different from other slide tools?
faq.answer: NotebookLM generates pedagogically-aligned content with proficiency-calibrated language and narrative structure.
